newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine bonds rise on S&P news, U.S. Treasuries.
newsitem.headline: Argentine bonds rise on S&P news, U.S. Treasuries.

text.p: Argentine bonds finished much higher Tuesday, boosted by news from Standard & Poor's that it had raised the counterparty ratings of five Argentine financial institutions and on rising U.S. Treasuries.
"At the end of the day there were lots of buyers," said a trader at a local bank.
Argentina's FRB Brady bond due 2005 rose 5/8 to 90-1/4, while the dollar-denominated Bocon Previsional 2 rose $0.20 to 125.75.
Another trader said the market "broke technical resistance," and predicted further gains Wednesday.
"The market closed with enthusiastic buyer interest for many bonds," said the second trader.
The news from S&P did not boost the government bond market directly, but the indirect impact from the cheer in the stock market and for corporate bonds gave it impetus.
In effect, S&P announced that Argentina's sovereign credit rating will no longer act as a ceiling to its ratings on Argentine corporates.
In the money markets, call money rates fell to 5.63 percent from 5.90 percent.
